variant.question: You are about to pass overhead a DME station at FL300 with an true ground speed of 300 kt.What would your DME instrument read?

options.text: Ground speed less than 300 kt and 5 DME
Ground speed 300 kt and 5 DME
Ground speed 300 kt and 7 DME
Ground speed less than 300 kt and 7 DME

variant.question: A VOR and DME are co-located. You want to identify the DME by listening to the callsign. Having heard the same callsign 4 times in 40 seconds the:

options.text: DME callsign is the one with the higher pitch that was broadcast only once
DME callsign is the one with the lower pitch that was broadcast several times
VOR and DME callsigns were the same and broadcast with the same pitch
DME callsign was not transmitted, the distance information is sufficient proof of correct operation

variant.question: A VOR and DME are co-located. During an ident cycle of 40 seconds, four call sign transmissions are received.The DME call sign is...

options.text: the one with the higher pitch that was broadcast only once.
the one with the lower pitch that was broadcast more than once.
not transmitted as the distance information is sufficient proof of correct operation.
the same as the VORâ€™s and broadcast with the same pitch.

variant.question: A DME station is co-located with a VOR station. Which of the following statements is true?

options.text: Both stations have the same ident transmitted at different tones.
Both stations have different idents transmitted at the same tone.
Both stations have the same ident transmitted at the same tone.
Both stations have different idents transmitted at different tones.

variant.question: A DME station is co-located with a VOR station.Which of the following statements is true?

options.text: Both stations have the same ident transmitted at different tones.
Both stations have different idents transmitted at different tones.
Both stations have different idents transmitted at the same tone.
Both stations have the same ident transmitted at the same tone.

variant.question: A VOR and DME are co-located. You want to identify the DME by listening to the Morse code identifier (call sign). Having heard the same Morse identifier 4 times in 40 seconds the:

options.text: DME Morse ident is the one with the higher pitch that was broadcast only once.
VOR and DME Morse idents were the same and broadcast with the same pitch.
DME Morse ident is the one with the lower pitch that was broadcast several times.
DME Morse ident was not transmitted, the distance information is sufficient proof of correct operation.

variant.question: A pilot is climbing to the cruising level and observing the DME ground speed indication. Which of the following statements is true about the DME ground speed indication and the real ground speed in this situation?

options.text: The DME ground speed is less than the real ground speed because the distance in climb change less than the distance on the ground.
If the aircraft is climbing directly towards the DME station, the DME ground speed and the real ground speed are the same.
If the aircraft is climbing straight away from the DME station., the DME ground speed and the real ground speed are the same .
The DME ground speed is less than the real ground speed because the distance in climb change more than the distance on the ground.

variant.question: Which statement is correct according to ICAO DOC 8168?

options.text: The aircraft has to be established within half scale deflection of the LLZ before starting descent on the GP.
The pilot has to fly the ILS GP to a maximum of 0.14Â° fly up deflection of the GP in order to stay in protected airspace.
The accuracy the pilot has to fly the ILS LLZ to be considered established on an ILS track is within full-scale deflection of the required track.
The pilot has to fly the ILS GP to a maximum of 0.08Â° fly up deflection of the GP in order to stay in protected airspace.

variant.question: Which statement is correct according to ICAO DOC 8168?

options.text: The aircraft has to be established within half scale deflection of the LLZ before starting descent on the GP.
The pilot has to fly the ILS GP to a maximum of 1/5 fly up deflection of the GP in order to stay in protected airspace.
The pilot has to fly the ILS GP to a maximum of Â¼ fly up deflection of the GP in order to stay in protected airspace.
The accuracy the pilot has to fly the ILS LLZ to be considered established on an ILS track is within Â¼ scale deflection of the required track.

variant.question: Which one is the most correct statement regarding a DME system?

options.text: Its maximum range is within "line of sight".
It operates in the VHF frequency band.
It operates on the principle of phase comparison.
It has unlimited range due to ground wave propagation.
